description.text: I recently made a cable holder for my banana cables in my lab (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1023662). It is really nice to get a bit of order in there. However, the smaller cables did not hang perfectly in that rake, so now I have made another design for 3 mm alligator cables. I showed the 6 mm holder to one of the mechanical engineers at my work, and he immediately spotted some areas where his FEM analysis would explode (sharp edges -> forces going towards infinit). These areas have also been fixed in this design.

Parachute mount for DJI Phantom 3
http://33dev.ru/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=55 VIDEO OF INSTALL https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cdipKr9Fhrk You will need: 1) Parachute 50" (http://33dev.ru/index.php?route=product/product&path=59&product_id=56) 2) 4 fasteners (2mm) to fix the mount on Phantom's legs 3) rubber band (25 mm width, around 200 mm length) to hold the parachute. 4) 6-9 g servomotor for release mechanism 5) Additional legs (27mm) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1029960 6) (optional) RC-01 Adaptor to use servomotor with Stop Flyaway system (http://33dev.ru/index.php?route=product/product&path=59&product_id=57) It will allow you to activate parachute when Phantom does not respond to original controller and flies away. Review the photos how to mount everything. Feel free to ask any questions.

Although I tried to make the model similar to the real thing, it is not a 100% replica, you are welcome to remix and improve on this! Thanks! UPDATE It's pretty hard to print the bottom of the model, so I have added a new file with the object split in half, this way you can print two copies and glue em together.

So this is my first designed thing ever and it was to fix my computer chair. 
I have a nice comfy computer chair, except recently the height adjustment cylinder no longer holds pressure and it slowly falls over the course of a few minutes. It's very annoying as I can't comfortable use the computer with the chair low and have to raise it again repeatedly. So I designed a piece to snap onto the bar shaft and keep it from collapsing. 
I doubt this will help many others but figured I'd post it just in case. Design file attached if anyone wants to mod the size for their own chair. Be warned, I only had about 1 hour of tutorial watching before I designed this. Still cutting my teeth on this whole 3D design thing.

Print
Snap onto shaft

title: Tengo-Class Assault Vessel from the Heavy MetalGods Role Playing Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Tengo-class is still used by Imperial Troops during planetary assaults and by Imperial Ground forces when quick deployment of troops is necessary. The Tengo-class sports impressive armament for a vessel of such a small size and can even carry up to two full-scale mecha.
On lots of water worlds older Tengo-class vessels are often used by traders and whole clans to travel from one place to another. You can download the Tengo either as one-piece 3D model or as two separate files of which the first one contains the main hull only sans all the guns and small detail parts, while the second one contains all the small parts that might be hard to print in 3D as an one-piece model. Feel free to leave me a comment and enjoy the Tengo! :-)

Custom middle plates and motor mounts for RCExplorers Tricopter V3. Allows you to mount Naze32 Flight Controller. Print all parts from ABS ,solid. You need the following to complete your build( If you don't own the kit) :
  • Aluminium Booms - 12mm or 10 mm.
  • M3 head hex screws with lock nuts.
  • Flight Controller - Naze32 or Flip32.
  • Motors 900-1000KV , ESCs 20A.
  • Lipo Battery - 3S or 4S.
  • Transmitter, receiver .
  • Propellers 1147 or 1045.
  • Wires and shrink tubes.
  • Zip-ties and Misc.

title: Hippo (made in Zbrush)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this model about 1.5 years ago...it will never be perfect but hey..
It was my first proper model..aww ;'D
I modelled it on reference photos but mainly a toy hippo.
I thought I'd share it with the community :D
Give 'something' back you know! I will release source files for peeps who are interested :) I will print it on my Sells Mendel soon and release pics...
(on thingiverse) That is if it is printable :S I have a 0.35 nozzle - the hippo model will need to be scaled up a bit..and maybe the teeth could be made bigger to help with resolution.. Here is a vid with some netfabb slicing action of this model! http://youtu.be/nfSj3J8oVbU?hd=1 Oh and I just discovered this :O http://www.thingiverse.com/thingiview:71045
This model will need support material unless you slice it into more segments with netfabb or other software.

This is a SPIDER KILLER! (or bug killer) the idea is that you have a 40mm fan between all the components and some other electrical components so that the fan will suck in the bugs and smash them against the fan and then discard the through out the back! and in the back you can attach a bag of some sort to catch the bugs, just make sure that air can go through the bag with a couple of holes in the bag or something. This 3D print is in super early beta and i do not know if it will work, you attach all the components with zip-ties. i'll have ebay links down below for what hardware i'll use. Things that you will need:
40mm fan, 40x40x28 with the holes at 32mm between them,
,9volt battery
, 9volt battery snap on connecter
, button
, soldering equipment or electrical tejp, zip ties. If you have any questions please post them in the comments and i'll answer as fast as i can.

title: Fallout - RobCo Keychain and Emblem
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I was able to find a lot of clothing and other items that had the company logo, but nothing in the 3D printed realm, so I made a model from the game art. The logo often has an "Established 20XX" date below the name, but at this size, I wasn't sure it would translate on the printer.
Enjoy.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1-0.3

Infill:

20+

Notes: I've done quite a few keychains and I always have the best of luck around 25% infill.

Blender Purist I'm not sure what's supposed to go here, but this is how I did it. I first found an image online that showed the logo.
I took the image and put it into InkScape where I adjusted the values to get it as close to black and white as possible.
Then, I used a process that is in InkScape to make vectors from the image. This gave me a vector of the text.
Export the vector and import it into blender to get a curve.
Blender has a process to extrude the curve and cap it.
Convert the curve to mesh.
I then create and refine the backing to the text and boolean the text's mesh and backing together.
Blender fixes the face (sort of) when you export to STL, so it's done at this point.

author: thomasneli

description.text:
Ultimaker X/Y rods sit in bearings that are pushed into the wooden frame. If the bearings are sticking out of the frame even a little, they'll cause drag on the rods and make it difficult to print at higher speeds.
This is a Thing that helps push the bearings evenly into the frame just a little bit.

• print with a slow, "high quality" profile
  • the round part on top is 0.5mm tall so a .25mm profile is probably best
  • carefully clean the circular top so it's nice and flat
  • remove one bolt from an endcap and rotate the cap out of the way - you probably will need to loosen the other bolt a little, too
  • use the Thing to push the bearing into the frame - it may take a bit of effort
  • reinsert the bolt and tighten things back up
  • repeat for each endcap
    • This is a pain to do on a machine that's already assembled - the endcap nuts are not really easily accessable once the pulleys and belts are installed. If you can print one (or get one printed) before assembly, it will be far easier to get the bearings seated correctly.

comments.text: Very handy tool!  I printed 2 and keep them in my "Ultimaker Essentials" tool kit.

This is a top bearing mount for P3steel 2.x Z-axis. Designed for use with M5 threaded rods and 625 ZZ bearing This top bearings prevent Z-axis threaded rods from vibrating while printing with high jerks and accelerations.
Stepper/rods coupler aren't made for taking loads. They compress and uncompress when they want to. This parts take the load from the coupler. Having a huge affect on print quality and layer thickness precision. Lock the threaded rods with Nyloc Nut DIN 985 as shown in the picture. Adjust the nuts that there is a little pretension on Z-coupler. It's the next part of a complete series for P3steel parts. I redesigned every part based on my long time experience with the P3 steel. Picture shows v1. Updates:
12.12.2015 - improved v2 with removable support structure now available Please share your makes! http://scheuten.me/?p=472

title: WANHAO Duplicator i3 top filament guide

description.text:
A simple filament guide for WANHAO Duplicator i3 printer. I prefer the top spool position, which is great but the filament tends to mess around as it unreels.
This filament guide makes the printer look clean and accurate and also reduces amount of plastic that unreels off the spool on its own. The mirrored version of the guide is also available if you prefer to feed your filament in front of the portal frame.

author: michielvdkeybus

description.text:
The Wishbone is a minimalist (and quite sturdy) smartphone stand.  It can be used both horizontally and vertically!  It is a bit less sturdy when used vertically on the side of your phone as shown in the fourth image, but still useful when you don't want it covering up your screen during videos, etc.
The STL file I've provided is in Millimeter, so I will also add the IPT file for those who wish to mess around with it in Inventor/change the units.  This will also allow you to re-size the phone slot for your specific device.  In it's current configuration, it fits my 8.2mm thinck Sony Xperia Z2 with .3mm of allowance.
I apologize for not including a picture of an actual phone in the stand, as I had to take the pictures on my phone.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

30-60

Notes: This was printed on a Flex Mendel. I am not able to advise on print settings, as your printer is probably way nicer and tuneable than mine.

The base screws to the meter with 3 mm screws (4 mm long) and is held in by the tabs.

This is a customizable stand for precision screwdrivers.
The thing makes it possible to position all your precision screwdrivers orderly and space efficiently.
In order to lock the screwdrivers in the stand and store it lying down, you can print a customizable top section that is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1044743. I find it quite convenient to store my screwdrivers as a package. I use a rubber band to keep the two parts together while in storage.

This is a plaque that I 3D print for the winner of our Tavern Brawl tournaments at our quarterly Hearthstone Fireside Gatherings. 
Feel free to add the date and location in Tinkercad using the Text Shape Generator (with the Tinos font). I find it easier to use a Sharpie to just write in the winner's name. 
For extra flash, you can duo-tone the print by pausing the printer and swapping out filament mid-print. I used woodfill and silver to great effect.

A super simple thing that I was surprised wasn't already here.
Spool clamps are used by luthiers to build violins and other stringed instruments. Typically they're made from a hardwood dowel with a threaded rod trilled through the center, with cork or leather lining the jaws.  They're great for clamping the edge of things without having to worry about the orientation of the clamp.
They cost about $4 each at a luthier supplier, which doesn't seem too much but you really need a couple dozen of them for any real project, and that starts to add up quickly.  Everyone says that it isn't any cheaper to make your own, but I figure plywood disks and carriage bolts are cheaper than that.  And I have a project I can use them on.
Two 1" disks.  One has a 0.26" hole in it for a 1/4" bolt.  The other has a 0.26" square to fit the square end of a carriage bolt.  I'm providing the OpenSCAD script and DXF files for each disk.

You need a 1/4" carriage bolt, a 1/4" fender washer, and a wing nut. You can use a regular bolt, but I'd suggest you use another washer on the other end. I used 1/4" plywood, with 1 square-hole disk, 5 round hole disks, and two round hole disks cut from 1/8" cork. The other is: square bit of carriage bolt
square hole disk
round hole disk
round hole disk
cork
<the thing you're clamping goes here - no glue>
cork
round hole disk
round hole disk
round hole disk
washer
wing nut Put a bit of glue between each of the wood/cork layers as you put them on the bolt. It clamps itself :) The glue is necessary - if you don't use it, the jaws of the clamp won't stay perpendicular. You can probably get away with two disks on each side of the clamp. I used three because that's close to what the traditional clamps look like.

title: Replacement Handle for Rival Crock Pot Lid

description.text:
The original lid for our crock pot cracked in several places and began to fall apart.  This is a replacement for it.  
The model with the flattened inside to the handle has not been tested but should work.  
SCAD file provided, so feel free to tweak.

Use a 1/4-20 nut and bolt.  The nut will fit very snugly, but should sink properly if you pull it in by turning the bolt.  The bolt used here was a 1" bolt cut to length.  
Print with supports.  Cleanup should be fairly easy if your printer is dialed in for support.  
Printed in ProtoParadigm Navy Blue it matches very well with the dark blue features on the crock pot.  
Be careful of temperature concerns.  Printed in PLA it can obviously get a little soft when the crock pot is at high heat.  When this one finally gives out I'll reprint with ABS and see how it does.

title: Tool rack for mounting on a 2020 frame 3D printer

description.text:
This is a tool rack I made for my Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3.  It is designed to hold the driver set I keep with the printer, which had rounded and tapered front ends on the handles, and wouldn't stand up right in a regular driver rack.  It also holds small scissors, small digital calipers, an xacto knife with a built in blade shield, and a pair of needle nose pliers.  The v3 holds needle nose pliers in a slot on one end, with an arm that can hold any kind of pliers or cutters at the other end.
This may be of use to others, even though I designed it specifically for my printer and tools.
V2 had a slot in the front for the drivers to be inserted and removed without having to pull them out the top or drop them in from the top.  I decided it didn't hold them straight enough to suit me, so I made V3 without the slots.  V3 also has the extra plier slot at the left.
V2 may work for pliers that are more flat on the bottom of the handle, so I left it.

I found the Sierpinsky Tetrix (or tetrahedron) and made a lamp out of it. I also created a version of the tetrix that does not need support and stands nicely.
The trick was to add some prismatic beams in the corners, which you don't see too much. The lamp is printed without support. The bed size needs to be 220x220 and also 250 height. But you can change the size yourself in the included scad source.

No

No

0.2

Notes: I must say it was very hard to print.
On the RepRaps you need to get the temperature and everything right such that the tetrahedra do not fall over. Make sure you have enough lift on travel moves.
Try the smaller tetrix first. You can also cut the lamp somewhere and try there and see whether everything works.
I ended up gluing mine together because the filament broke, so I printed the remaining part separately.
Also try to print the thread first (separate file) and if it does not fit modify the scad file.

description.text:
This is a holder for the Dronco 123 System Ergonomic Mini Sander and, optionally, holders for the sandpaper strips you use with them.
I decided I needed a holder for it because I spent 5 minutes searching for the little thing in my 'workshop'. And, yeah, this is the second Mini Sander I own. Where the first one is is anyone's guess. So it really needs a safe place.
It's not a very refined holder, but it works.
The OpenSCAD file is included to show how easy it is to hack together something like these holders. The Dronco_Holder is best prnted 'face down' and with support structures for the screw holes.
How many of the Dronco_Paper you print is up to you. I'm printing 3 since these sanders come with 3 different grades of paper. These should also be printed face down, but shouldn't need any support structures. Optionally, you could hack the file and make a custom holder that has room for more paper strips.
holder for fastening a c10 breakout board to a flat surface.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter
Designed using freecad http://www.freecadweb.org/

http://www.instructables.com/id/Interlocking-Building-Blocks/ I wanted to design a building block set that locked together so that the built structure would have more stability. I've seen too many Lego towers fall over to the dismay of the person working with them. It took several different tries and a few pounds of ABS plastic, but I believe I finally settled on a good modular shape that can be scaled quite nicely. As the files are they will produce 32X24.5mm cubes. Scaling down to 50% or even up to 200% has produced good results. How To Print: Printed the pieces on a RepRap at .5mm height. 20% infill. Single shell.
I would advice to just print the "squareBrick_Pallet.stl" to get a single of each of the 8 different parts to get a feel for how the pieces work. Then once you can get a ballpark of how many of each you want you can use the individual part STLs. How To Build: The thing to keep in mind is that all the pieces in the set are based around the single two main parts (squareBrick_Half and squareBrick_Whole). And each piece has both a whole(24mm high) and a half(12mm high) version. The key to the bricks strength is when you alter the height from half to whole parts and build the wall up from that.
When building, start with just those two pieces and build out the shape of the object you want. Then using the other six pieces you can go back and cap and cover the exposed joints.
I've included a CGI image to show ideas and to get you started on what goes where. Each color is a different piece, for 7 total (whole_cap_longer isn't shown in the picture, making a total of 8 different pieces in the set). Future Changes: I'd like to go back and alter the "cap_longer" pieces to fit inside corners.
Make some double length pieces. I wanted to keep the different piece count down to start with though.
Compatibility pieces. To connect to Legos and other building sets.

description.text:
This is my first thing i upload here... also my first work in FreeCAD (Installed 2h prior). So please give ideas on what to optimize and how to do better. I am a bloody beginner in this matter... It is a 2-part magnetic coupling intended to use with 2 rings.
Originally designed for archery (Arrow-puller is handy to be had at hand), but can be used for everything that incorporates 2 keyrings and need a quick magnetic coupling. Even 2 strings like paracords should work. Havent tested that and the hole may be a bit small. Can provide other hole-sizes (up to 6mm diameter) if necessary. The hole for the magnets is 10.0mm in diameter and made for 3mm thick magnets. The magnets don't touch: they are separated by 0.5mm so they don't shatter upon contact.
Since i am waiting for my magnets to arrive, i am unsure if i need to allow for a bigger (+0.2mm) hole and glue the magnets in... Will adjust if necessary and the magnets are a tad bigger than the 10.0mm. Time will tell. UPDATE:
I realized, that the tight fit for the magnet may not be the best option: Glue has no place, Magnets may be a bit bigger, print a bit smaller... and you end in a big problem assembling it.
Also in a testprint, i realized, that the sloped contact-face may not be the best choice: It tends to slip. By checking out other magnet-couplings, i saw, that most have a 90°-Face (plug in tube) philosophy.
So i added a Version 2. Changes against V1:
  • 90°-Connect instead of 45°
  • Hole of magnet allows for 0.5mm space around the magnet for glue and tolerances
  • The connecting plug and the tube also have 0.25mm spacing (radius) for a looser connect and therefore easier disconnect (allows for some angle of disconnect)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Print whatever you like.

Infill:

30+ for stability of the hole at the keyring

Notes: Best go with 100% infill. It is small, prints fast and will give most security against breaking.
Version 1 (45 degree) Version 2: Intended use (Magnet = red) Version 2: Side-by-side (Magnet = red) Version 2: Side-by-side (Magnet = red)

Shoppinglist The magnets i ordered are those:
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/50pcs-Bulk-mini-Small-Round-NdFeB-Neodymium-Disc-Magnets-Dia-10mm-x-3mm-N35-Super-Strong/32434157266.html
50 pcs for 4.20 US$ 50pcs for < 5 US$ @ Aliexpress.com

remixed_from.title: Z endstop support adjustable folgertech 2020 I3

title: Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3 Robust Adjustable Z Endstop

description.text:
I printed the endstop by psbox, but it broke during the install.  The problem is, that it was designed really thin, in order to get the switch under the part it needed to hit.  I made it more robust by moving the sensor board to the back side, and making the support thicker.  Works well for me.  I also included a knob that I use as a thumbscrew on the bolt, making it easier to adjust. 
I wanted something I could reach easily from the front of the printer, yet strong enough that it wouldn't move on it's own.
Assemble by putting a long M3 bolt through the knob, put a nut above the knob and tighten it down so turning the knob turns the bolt.  Then put the bolt through the bottom of the square housing, through a spring (I used a spare bed leveling spring), and through the square block and nut on the sensor mount part, then on out the top.  Put a washer and nylock nut on top.

Resolution:

description.text: UPDATE 2016-01-18 - The newer, prettier version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1271858. A few key improvements have been made, such as a stonework-like outer surface, and a more funnel-y top. Version 2 is definitely one version revision better than this one. This is a dice tower based loosely on Laura's Tower in Shrewsbury. I've included an .iges file as well. All the components are designed to print within the M3D build volume, and are designed to be connected using disc magnets. Edit 2015-10-21 - I realized that d20's escaped the side stair railings about 20% of the time. I uploaded "high wall" versions of the stairs. With 10mm extra height, it should keep those dice going down the stairs properly.

comments.text: What did you use to glue the magnets into place? I was thinking a two part epoxy, but wanted some input on what worked haha
comments.author: GameHippie

comments.text:
Plain old Cyanoacrylate Glue. (Gorilla brand superglue to be precise) It also helped that the holes were a snug fit on my magnets.
I used parchment paper (silicone-impregnated cooking paper stuff) on my desk top to avoid ruining it. I first "buttered up" the inside of the hole with glue, placed the magnet on top of the parchment paper, and pressed the tower segment down over the magnet, forcing it into the hole. The desk surface (which is protected by the parchment paper) made sure that the magnet was flush with the surface.

remixed_from.author: GlitchTech
remixed_from.title: Safe & Secure Raspberry Pi B2 Case - Camera & GPIO Cable Slots

description.text:
Turn your Raspberry Pi 2 and Raspberry Pi 7" Touchscreen into a completely custom tablet. This design is still a work in progress. Cable lengths and required hardware have not been tested/determined. Work is still on going to find a fitting battery to go inside. Features
  • Ability to mount the Screen to the shell without the use of glue on your screen.
  • Off center mounting location for Raspberry Pi for a larger empty area.
  • USB & Ethernet external access
  • GPIO external access (optional plug)
  • Pi Camera mount on back (optional dummy plug)
    • This design is derived from MCM Electronic's Raspberry Pi Tablet shell.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes: If you cannot print at 0.1mm resolution, it should still work. You will have to sand and trim the pieces though. Print List:
  • Shell
  • Pi Plate
  • Back Plate
  • GPIO Plug
    • Optional if you don't use the GPIO
  • Camera Insert or Camera Dummy Plug
    • Print the dummy plug only if you are not using the Raspberry Pi Camera
  • Mount Frame

Finishing Test fit all pieces together. Depending on printer settings and resolution, pieces may need to be sanded or shaved down slightly. Display Adapter Board
  • Start with all components disassembled, as received originally.
  • Connect the display ribbon cable to the back of the Adapter Board.
  • Set the Adapter Board onto the back of the display then connect the touch screen ribbon cable.
    • See the official Build Instructions if you need more information.
  • Use the four (4) screws to attach the Adapter Board to the back of the display.
    • Raspberry Pi
  • Place the Raspberry Pi in the Pi Plate.
  • Use M3 x 5mm sheet metal screws to affix the Pi in place.
    • Screw type is not yet tested
    • Display
  • Place the Shell face up.
    • Camera cut out against the table
    • GPIO port on your right
    • Up is same wall as the Camera cut out.
  • Test fit Mount Point A pieces. These fit over little triangles on the walls.
    • Two pieces go on either side of the Camera cut out.
    • One piece goes in the bottom left.
  • Glue Mount Point A pieces in place.
  • Test fit Mount Point B pieces. Similar fitting points to the previous pieces.
    • One piece goes on bottom wall.
    • One piece goes on right wall (next to GPIO).
  • Glue Mount Point B pieces in place.
  • Let glue dry.
  • Place Display face down on a soft surface.
  • Flip over the Shell and place on Display. The screen should fit snugly in place.
  • Using three (3) machine screws, attach the Display to the Shell.
    • The size of these screws has not yet been determined.
    • Camera
  • Test fit the Camera Insert or the Camera Dummy Plug in the Back Plate. The camera piece will be flush with the outside of the Back Plate.
  • Glue the camera piece in place.
    • If you are using the Camera Insert, align the low side of the plug towards the top.
    • If you are using the Camera Dummy Plug, skip the rest of this section.
  • Attach the Camera Module to the Camera Insert with M2 sheet metal screws. These are the same ones that typically come with a servo for attaching items to the servo horn.
    • The cable from the camera should go to the low side of the plug.
  • Attach the Camera Cable
    • Electronics
  • Place the Shell with mounted Display face down on a soft surface.
    • GPIO port should be on your left now.
  • (Optional) Attach the camera cable to the Raspberry Pi. This may require the Back Plate to sit half on the Shell.
  • Attach the DSI ribbon cable to the Raspberry Pi.
    • See the official Build Instructions if you need more information.
  • (Optional) Insert the GPIO Plug in the GPIO hole on the Shell.
  • Insert the Pi Plate with mounted Raspberry Pi in its slot in the bottom left of the Shell.
  • Attach the other end of the DSI ribbon cable to the Display Adapter.
  • Use one (1) M4 x 15mm sheet metal screws to affix the Pi in place.
    • Screw type is not yet tested.
    • Instructions for Power systems coming soon
    As of now, you must run your power lines in via the GPIO hole. Final Assembly
  • Place the Back Plate on the Shell.
  • Use three (3) M4 x 15mm sheet metal screws to affix the Back Plate to the Shell.
    • Screw type is not yet tested.

Future Changes
  • Internally mounted battery
    • The plan is to use PowerBoost 1000 and a LiPoly Battery - 2500mAh. Once I get the parts, I'll set up the mounting system.
  • Insert for PI/Display power connection access
    • Updates 2015 October 23
  • Created mounting frame to replace individual mount points
  • Adjusted mounting hole locations
  • Increase wiggle room on mounting system
    • 2015 October 05
  • Redesigned shell and mounting points to require less support.
  • Modified Pi Plate to add screw point.
  • Modified Shell to better fit the Raspberry Pi Screen.
  • Added new Mounting Point components.
  • Modified Back Plate screw hole locations for new mounting system.

description.text:
A collection of wings (and more soon) to integrate with ThinkFun Maker Studio. Make working gliders, rubber band launched rockets, and (maybe soon, who knows...) mechanically powered planes and helicopters. You can find the 3 official Maker Studio sets here (1,2,3) Cool wing info: Airfoil: Clark Y
Cord Length: 3.5"
Attachment Angle of Attack: 2.13 deg
CL @ 2.13 deg: ~.55
CL max: ~1.5
CD min: ~.01-~.02 Learn more about the Clark Y and other airfoils at Airfoiltools These wing sections use a Clark Y airfoil. Created in 1922, this is one of the most popular airfoils of early flight. It was used on Charles Lindbergh's "Spirit of St. Louis" for the first solo transatlantic flight. Due to its flat bottom, the Clark Y is easy to manufacture and remains popular among hobbyist to this day. Let me know how well yours fit together! Mine snap in just right. Feel free to edit, alter, modify, or otherwise do whatever you like with these. I've included a .STEP of on of the capped wings. If you do make a derivative or otherwise use these in something you post, please give credit and share alike!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Print 4x wing-1, 1x propeller-copter, 2x all others May need light sanding under the nose For even better (less drag) flight, put masking tape over the bottom of the wing, covering the connectors and any bare slots to make the bottom a smooth surface.

comments.text:
The .step files may be of help, if you are really thinking of flying the wing, I need to make ailerons, if not spoilers and slats..
And maybe a place for mounting a servo .. and mounting points.. Then look at the wing loading and how strong the main spar needs to be.. As you can tell making a usable wing is another big step...
I am thinking of printing a 18" electric Piper Cub, and so that is why I was checking out you wing..
